Award.AwardTitle: Eight Societies Travel Grants for Graduate Students, Independent Scholars, & Recent PhDs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Overview

This proposal requests funds to enable eight professional societies in history, philosophy, and social studies of science and technology to provide travel grants to graduate students, independent scholars, and junior scholars between 2014 and 2016. The grants would enable these scholars to participate in some of these professional meetings, those that are pertinent to their professional development. Their participation would facilitate the dissemination of their research results and provide opportunities to engage in professional networking.

Intellectual Merit

Such professionalization is crucial on several fronts. Younger scholars will be teaching at major research universities, liberal arts colleges, and community colleges; they are also engaged in curating museum exhibits, working at research institutes, overseeing library collections, and helping with government programs. Independent scholars need to maintain contact with their professional societies to promote intellectual and practical stimulation as they continue to work in museums, research institutes, libraries, and government agencies. Finally, recent PhDs face severe cuts in departmental travel funds; travel grants will facilitate the maintenance of their career trajectories. Assisting these groups serves to enhance the STEM workforce, which in turn serves to advance NSF's core mission by improving science literacy and by enhancing the scientific process.

Broader Impacts

The cooperation that this grant will require will serve to maintain relationships across the eight societies, which represent divergent fields. It also facilitates international interactions enabling scholars to travel overseas as they share their research and develop networks. This exchange enhances the intellectual quality of the meetings, while fostering diverse viewpoints and interpretations of science. As the US sees its share of college enrollees in the world dwindle, it is all the more important that these eight societies, all of them with an international membership with the lion's share of its members in the US, share ideas and questions about science and its influence on society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant's primary goal is to gain a clearer understanding of how science and technology advance so that we can more effectively use these powerful elements of human achievement. This grant helps us reach that goal by allowing graduate students, independent scholars, and junior scholars to attend the professional meetings of 8 professional societies, thus enriching our discussions of science and technology.

Because the 8 societies focus on science, technology and the environment and their impact on society, these groups are uniquely positioned to provide insights into scientific practice and decision making. The benefits of science and technology are self evident, but with a greater appreciation of how these benefits are achieved, by looking at the process of discovery, for example, the public learns how discoveries and breakthroughs are made, making the citizenry better prepared to evaluate scientific, technological, and environmental arguments. This understanding is essential for any democracy to thrive.

The societies administer these grants parsimoniously in order to share the awards widely. We realize that even modest grants provide a tremendous boost for these scholars. For HSS, the average amount of the 115 reimbursements was $231.28. The average for ASEH’s 29 grants was $393.99 and for SLSA the average was $179.54. PSA had an average grant size of $162.81 and HOPOS averaged $429.20.  The highest average of the societies that met in the last year was SHOT's $890.48, which was due to their meeting in Singapore, which allowed greater contact with scholars in Asia. Even with these modest amounts, many grantees are able to cobble together funds from other sources and the NSF grants help them in their search for these monies. We are careful to make sure that there is no overlap in funding, asking each recipient to sign a form that he or she did not receive other money for NSF reimbursements.

By sharing the NSF funds widely, we help as many scholars as possible attend the meetings. This increases diversity at the meetings (more women, more students, more independent scholars, and more recent PhDs), thus benefitting the conferences themselves. The range of research is wider, more communities with shared research interests can gather together, and the overall quality of the conferences is heightened.  

For its Singapore conference, SHOT disbursed 21,grants, 17 of them to graduate students. Of these 21 grant recipients, 10 were Caucasian, 5 were Asian, 1 was hispanic, (5 were non-reporting). This group furthermore consisted of 13 males and 8 females. 

The HSS, PSA, and SLSA held a joint meeting in Atlanta, GA for their 2016 conference. Attendance remained steady, with 1,613 participants making the trip to Atlanta with 621 of them attending for the HSS meeting. The number of students attending for HSS was slightly down, with 133 students compared to 185 in 2015 and 197 for 2014. (Note: these totals include the student volunteers who work the registration tables in exchange for registration each year, many of whom are travel grant recipients). However, the proportion of students as a percentage of the total attendance remained steady.  The proportion of students for PSA was similar, with 150 students out of 593 PSA registrants (25%). SLSA had the highest proportion of students with 174 out of 427 paid registrants (41%) reporting as graduate students.

ASEH had tremendous success increasing student participation; at their Chicago meeting in 2017 121 out of 624 total participants (19.4%) were graduate students. 

There was a rise across the board of awards made to each category of applicant. HSS gave grants to 12 independent scholars, (only 2 in 2015), 31 recent PhDs, a 50% increase from last year, and 72 graduate students, which is a 43% increase. Need among recent PhDs, who often work as adjunct faculty with no access to travel funds, has become increasingly visible among members of the Society. Special sessions in recent meetings have considered ways to address this need, including the use of NSF travel funds to support early-career scholars. Testimonials from this year’s meeting repeatedly emphasize the crucial role that funds for meeting attendance play in the careers of contingent faculty and independent scholars, a group that merits special consideration.

Although an important byproduct of the travel grants is how they improve the diversity and breadth of the societies’ academic conferences, another key element is the impact that they wield on these scholars’ lives. Although metrics for such effects are difficult to establish, the recipients’ society membership and conference attendance are suggestive. We can look at general trends in gender equity, grad-student representation and the number of independent scholars at the meetings, as well as how many of these individuals join the societies, but assessing individual impact is best represented by testimonials. We have collected dozens of these, representing broad impacts.
